heading: riaa rains on lycos' mp3 party
subheading: hours after the search company releases a tech that helps people find mp3 files on the web, the recording industry steps in to call foul.
author: wired news report
text: lycos will work with the recording industry association of america to ensure the company's new mp3 search engine does not link to illegal sites, the associated press reported tuesday. the internet company unveiled a search engine monday that can find mp3 files located on the net, and the riaa is concerned that the service will facilitate online music piracy. mp3 is a popular format that makes music files fast and easy to transmit over the internet, while retaining high quality sound.the riaa released a statement shortly after the lycos search went live, saying the organization had enlisted lycos to combat copyright infringement."we have agreed to work together on this and we will do what we are required to do," lycos spokesman brian payea told the ap.lycos is in the process of acquiring wired digital, the parent company of wired news.full story to follow.
